description: Augmented Reality statue for Brixton in conversation with Brixton Police station on the legacy of 1981's Uprising. She breaths & tells a challenging story of loss, love & justice. We discuss the potential for AR to tell hidden narratives.

factsheet.heading: About the Statue Marcia Rigg
paragraphs: This statue is the first in a  series of AR-Statues designed to intervene into the public realm and offer alternative, more equitable & diverse ideas of what and who statues can be.

The embody living people, who are 'making history' and should be celebrated and venerated for it. People who're alive and thus able to question and be questioned.
Marcia Rigg is a living civil rights campaigner who we felt should be celebrated for her work bringing scrutiny on police conduct and retaining focus on the relationship between police and the Black community. - She offers a role model who we rarely see venerated in our public spaces, a strong black women, rather than another dead 'great white man', and like history she is not set in stone, she is continuing to fight for change and justice.
Marcia's brother Sean Rigg died in Police custody in 2008, after being arrested and held face down in a prone position for 8 mins, not too dissimilar to George Floyd. Marcia returns to the square every year placing flowers on what has become known as the 'memorial tree'. Her AR-statue is in dialogue with this place, she stands offering flowers as an act of love in one hand and  the other holds vigil candle in a fist, a sign of black solidarity and resilience.
Situated in the square in front of Brixton Police station, her statue also serves to catalyse progressive conversations between the MET and Brixton's Community. Whilst it is a challenging reminder for the MET, it is also one they have chosen to support and embrace.

Accessed via an App downloaded on visitors phones, her statue appears within the phones live camera view, accompanied by the sound of her breath. Users can also hear  her speak of the emotions and motivations behind her statue.
“Hearing the sound of my breath is important. I’m here, I’m alive, I’m not going anywhere. For this is a living statue and I’m telling our story” -  Marcia Rigg

More Info & Audio Interviews with Marcia here:
https://www.aswarm.com/holding-the-flame/

factsheet.heading: About the Artist & partners
paragraphs: Aswarm is an international award winning, artist lead company based in Brixton, who create interactive and immersive installations largely in public and site specific spaces. Renowned for their innovative use of sound within public art, Aswarm create art that transforms how spaces function and that invite people to explore a sense of agency over our public realm.

Led by Artist Thor McIntyre-Burnie ( Director of Aswarm), this project represents a collaboration with technologists Gesture Ltd, producers The Brixton Project, commissioners 81 Acts and campaign group United Friends and Family Campaign, via Marcia Rigg.
